newsitem.title: USA: Cyrix sees top PC vendor for GX chip.
newsitem.headline: Cyrix sees top PC vendor for GX chip.

text.p: Cyrix Corp Senior Vice President of Finance Jay Swent said that the company will introduce a processor compatible with Intel Corp's Pentium chip aimed at PC's costing $1,000 and under in the current quarter with a "top tier" personal computer maker.
Swent declined to be more specific about which leading PC makers have agreed to use the chip, which is called a GX processor.
He also said that the GX chip will be adopted by Asian PC makers, such as Tatung Co Ltd and others.
Swent also said that after a difficult 1996, in which Cyrix reported a net loss, he is confident that the company has improved its balance sheet and is on the road to improved profits.

"In our conference call, we talked about a model in the 30 percent range," he said refering to the company's target gross profit margin range of 30 percent of revenues. "I think we can stay consistently in the above 30 percent margin range."
He also said that Cyrix will begin shipping in volume near the end of the second quarter a chip, code named the M2, which is compatible with Intel's MMX multimedia architecture.
